title: Geth v1.10.6 on full sync, archive mode is slow at around 1-2 blocks per minute
body:
The current block in our node is around 12.3M. It takes around 1 minute to sync a new block. Is this normal? We have updated our GETH to stay aligned with the London fork. but at this slow rate, It would take months to reach the forking block. We are running it on a K8s (8 cores and 64 GB) cluster with an Azure premium SSD of 16TB attached. Attaching the Grafana [snapshot](https://snapshot.raintank.io/dashboard/snapshot/SIgYtW46RI4M6nXs1Hv7woCzbYlDAGTX) for reference.
These are my arguments `--cache=65536 --syncmode=full --gcmode=archive --datadir=/data/eth --nousb --maxpeers=20`.
I have seen people using `--snapshot=false`. Whats change does it make?  Suggestions to improve the rate of sync are highly appreciated!

I am experiencing the same issue, here are the flags we are using: `--ipcdisable --syncmode=full --cache=4096 --maxpeers=50 --nat=none --datadir=/data/backend --port=38336 --ws --ws.addr=0.0.0.0 --ws.port=8036 --http.api=web3,eth,net,txpool,debug --gcmode=archive --txlookuplimit=0` this is becoming a nighmare where I cant awake :~ I already moved to a 16 Core 64GB RAM machine with CPU optimization under GKE and it did not improved much...

Hey, guys. We are experiencing the very same issues here with our 2 Geth nodes (1 full and 1 archive). What makes our situation even worse is that we missed the hardfork initially, and when we realized and updated we were 7k blocks behind.
Now it's 10k blocks behind. Is there any patch or something planned? Or should we reconfigure our nodes somehow?

Here is all my config info to debug:
https://gist.github.com/ArseniiPetrovich/c7f163394a531843f1d596a1d0c2e1ec


P.S. For now I noticed that if we restart Geth node, the situation getting better for 30 mins or something, so we used this [instruction](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31055194/how-can-i-configure-a-systemd-service-to-restart-periodically) to setup a temporary solution that restart Geth each 30 minutes, but that is definitely is just a temporary workaround.

I have enabled `--snapshot=false`, increased the `--cache`, and reduced the `--maxpeers`. Now I am getting a block processing time of around 5 seconds per block hence 10 blocks are synced per minute. I still believe it is slow compared to the hardware which is provided.
Update. My idea with restart every 30 minutes worked, I catched up with the network, however there definitely should be a better way of doing that.
@ArseniiPetrovich Did your 30 min restart work on the archive or the full node?

@ArseniiPetrovich @jithin03 If we give you an influxdb metrics endpoint, would you mind configuring your node for a bit to push metrics to there so we might take a look as to what it's doing?

For full nodes with huge caches, the garbage collector might be hit. It should be visible on the metrics. For archive nodes I'm not so sure.

Most of the charts are empty for me (perhaps you only exported the visible charts?). The dashboard seems also older, I think this is our newest one: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/karalabe/5b4f2639d750f8925a49cd48817370df/raw/519be0cadc11e2f5362d5c2918999aa0e6d49ea0/geth.json

@karalabe We recently started another node from snapshot and it seems it still sync VERY slow. Is there any tips so far?

@ArseniiPetrovich looking at your charts now. Here's the archive processing

![Screenshot 2021-11-04 at 19-46-46 Single Geth - Grafana](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/142290/140401261-2b174251-2774-4635-a5be-8138f972cbeb.png)

What seems to be slow is storage read and account read. 

The full-node is faster than the archive: 
![Screenshot 2021-11-04 at 19-49-30 Dual Geth - Grafana](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/142290/140401568-dd999cd2-7965-46fb-83d1-a1f2b6be5c7b.png)

But that's not surprising, a non-archive node has more data in memory, whereas the archive flushes to disk very often. Mem charts: 

![Screenshot 2021-11-04 at 19-50-19 Dual Geth - Grafana](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/142290/140401726-59c61b47-363a-43e2-8e18-e26403d4f3de.png)

I can also see that you're not using snapshots -- so yeah, there's a _lot_ of disk lookups on a non-snapshot archive node, made even worse by the fact that your leveldb database is `9TB` for the archive.

I don't really see anything here which is a _bug_ per se. Running an archive node is extremely IO heavy. 

However, they're both way faster than 1-2 blocks per minute, as the title says -- the mean for the archive seems to be sub 1 second per block.
Oh yeah, sorry for not following up on this sooner, and thanks for configuring the nodes so we could investigate it bit closer.

Hey, @holiman, thank you for taking a look there! Well, after the node is synced up there are no problems with them, and that is what you are seeing, the node behaves really well when synced. Do you happen to have the data for the period prior to full synchronization? I just don't think we are ready to force our node to fall back behind the chain once again to check the sync process.

Other questions:
1) If I enable snapshots - this will speed up the sync? Will the node remain archive in that case?
2) Are you saying that the bottleneck is the disk IOPS currently?

Thank you for getting back to me! :)
Does this essentially come down to disk IOPS?
